title: Determination of Elemental Concentrations in Lichens Using ICP-AES/MS
procedures: Sample preparationSample preparation for microwave digestion – ICP-MSThe lichen samples (> 200 g per sample, fresh weight) are air-dried at room temperature in paper bags for at least 5 days. Carefully remove soil particles and other debris on lichen thalli under a stereo microscope using clean tweezers.The cleaned samples are oven-dried at 70 °C for 72 h to constant weight (determined by weighting each sample at an interval of 8-12 h). Cool down the samples to room temperature and ground each sample to powder in a grinding mill, then pass each sample through a 10 mesh nylon sieve.Transfer an accurately weighted portion of each sample (0.3000 g) to a Teflon digestion vessel. Add 4.0 ml HNO3 to the vessel and incubate for 4 h at room temperature. Then add 2.0 ml H2O2, and transfer the digestion vessel to a microwave digestion system (MARS-X), applying the following temperature control procedure (Table 1).Table 1. Dilute the sample to 50 ml with deionized water for ICP-MS testing.Prepare blank samples and certified reference material samples (IAEA-336, GBW10010, GBW10014 and GBW10015) according to the above mentioned procedures.Sample preparation for microwave digestion – ICP-MSTransfer an accurately weighted portion of each sample (1.0000 g) of the lichen (obtained in step A1b) to a nickel crucible and then all samples are heated to 500 °C until they turn grayish white (and therefore are fully ashed).Add 1.5 g of NaOH to decompose each sample at 700 °C for 10 min.

Cool down all samples to room temperature and wash each sample into a 50 ml plastic centrifuge tube using hot deionized water (70-80 °C, 20-30 ml). To ensure complete transfer of each sample, also wash the nickel crucible according to the method mentioned above. The results show that both methods had low detection limits and wide linear ranges.Accuracy and precision of the methodsPrepare and decompose the certified reference materials (IAEA-336, GBW10014 and GBW10015) followed steps A1 and A2. The sample is analyzed with 8 technical replicates using ICP-AES/MS under optimal operating conditions (Tables 2 and 5). A comparison of the measured values with certified values is shown in Tables S1[href=https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/file/20170207/20170207012150_4297.docx] and S2[href=https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/file/20170207/20170207012415_8687.docx] for ICP-MS and ICP-AES analysis, respectively.
The results show that both methods have a good accuracy (relative error < 10%) and precision (relative standard deviation ranging from 1.56% to 9.55%).
